docs.lead_paragraph: To the Business Editor: Concerning ''Aid to Humanities'' (Oct. 26), would Mr. Banner say that the Europeans, the Japanese, the Koreans and others are beating the pants off us in the sale of steel products, motor cars, electronic products, shoes, clothing, and other items because of their superior knowledge in those branches of learning having to do with matters cultural - poetry, history, philosophy, the theater, the dance, fine arts, oratory and similar easily digested delicacies? Our fellow men in other parts of this globe have found better ways to produce better things through steel manufacturing processes, car assembly lines, integrated circuits and printed circuit boards, methods of spinning fibers, weaving, stitching, sewing, and in the ability to transport their products all over the seven seas.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Business Editor: James M. Banner's clarion call for corporate aid to the humanities has a silly side to it as well. I love funding, but I want to see it done efficiently and with the minimum of hypocrisy. What good is it for the heads of Exxon and MCA to hand big checks to the officials of Yale and Boston Univerisities if at the same time, and on the same campuses, recruiters from Exxon and MCA are telling our humanities majors that their education has been wasted? That their studies in history or English or philosophy leave them without any marketable skills, and that they have been disqualified for a career at Exxon or MCA?

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Business Editor: ''Aid to Humanities'' (Oct. 26) is right on target: In higher learning today, we need to re-emphasize the ''liberal education,'' the kind that cultivates our minds and characters, communicates and affirms ethical normality and helps one develop the moral and intellectual refinements required to distingush between truth and error, right and wrong, noble and base. Such an education demands the rigorous examination of and reflection on the accumulated wisdom of the past. If one is interested in the nature of justice and of law, what contemporary works can compare with the writings of Plato, Cicero and Aquinas?

docs.lead_paragraph: Several humanists gathered in New Haven last weekend for a Yale University symposium on ''The Humanities and the Public Interest.'' Excerpts from the remarks of Norman Podhoretz, the editor of Commentary magazine, and A. Bartlett Giamatti, Yale's president, follow. PODHORETZ: Contempt and Conformity I do not believe that the humanities need to be or indeed can be plausibly justified in merely instrumental terms. My view is that they are good for their own sweet sake and need no other justification.
